instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Overheating Around USB-C area
threads.message: Got this one here and it was not turning on. There was corrosion around <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> area and some missing resistors there. I managed to get the board working again after placing missing components and cleaning up the area. Machine is working ok, except when I connect power to left USB-C port nearest the trackpad. When I connect power there, the area around <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR> heats so much that cooler kicks in full blast and to the point even turning the machine off and area gets REALLY hot to touch, to the point of burning the finger. All other ports behave ok and no heating at all. Tried replacing USB-C port, replaced <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>, <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR>/<TRANSISTOR>Q3200</TRANSISTOR>, CC772, CB211, CC773, <CAPACITOR>C3509</CAPACITOR>/08/07 but still same issue. Any ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Overheating Around USB-C area
threads.message:
Check with thermal cam what exactly gets hot there.
Compare diode mode readings between both channels of J3300; or compare with right connector, JB500.

Machine still works when connect power to that port?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Overheating Around USB-C area
threads.message: If I had a thermal cam I'd do it haha. Machine works with power connected to it and even charges battery normally, but turns itself off after some minutes due to overheating. Will need to compare diode between ports still...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Overheating Around USB-C area
threads.message: Now board is heating outside the case too on that specific port and I could trace what's heating. It's <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR>. I've replaced this twice and issue persists.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Overheating Around USB-C area
threads.message:
Maybe it is not correctly controlled by <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>.
Check their traces, replace <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> again.
Compare <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR>/200 voltages, when MLB is powered on these ports.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Overheating Around USB-C area
threads.message: Replaced <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> again, same thing. <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR>/3200 got same voltages

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Overheating Around USB-C area
threads.message:
Did you check Q/<CHIP>U3100</CHIP> traces?
If G2/<TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR> (pin 4) doesn't have good contact, <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR> overheats.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Overheating Around USB-C area
threads.message: Yes, trace is good. I even removed again <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR> and measured resistance between PIN 9 of <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and PIN 4 of <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR> and it's less than 1OHM resistance.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Overheating Around USB-C area
threads.message:
If <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR> is correctly driven, shouldn't get hot; should have less than 10 miliohm I/O internal ressistance.
It must get at least 5V more on each Gate pin than corresponding Source pin.
Check that difference comparing with the other MOSFETs.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Overheating Around USB-C area
threads.message: Well. I got some more boards here from the same model and ALL of them have the same heating behavior when charging. And I noticed that it's on all ports. I think this is an expected behavior and not a problem.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Overheating Around USB-C area
threads.message: If all ports have the same behavior, then is OK.
